metadata.title: Investigation of strength and hydration characteristics in nano-silica incorporated cement paste

sections.text:
M AN
US CR
AC CE
PT ED
A hydration model for Portland cement pastes modified with nano-silica in partial substitution is formulated based on the nucleation growth process from microstructural investigations over time. The model is calibrated against thermogravimetry, X-ray diffraction and calorimetry data for four different substitution rates from 0 to 12 wt% and is validated by backscattered electron microscopy. Finite element based compressive strength predictions using representative volume element analysis of the nano modified cement pastes agreed with the experimental values. The model predictions indicate that a rate of 8 wt% is the optimum replacement level of cement by nano-silica leading to a high density matrix promoting a maximum mechanical strength.
Keywords: cement paste, nano-silica, hydration modelling, compressive strength modelling, X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA)
M AN
US CR
IP T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The concepts of nanomaterials and nanotechnology emerged in the last two decades and have affected various sectors including cement and concrete research. Effects of using nanomaterials as replacement for cement in concrete (at very small replacement levels) have been of great research interest; especially with carbon nano tubes, nano-silica, nano-TiO2, nano-Fe2O3 and nano-Al2O3 [1, 2]. These nanomaterials act as fillers within the paste providing nucleation sites for the hydration reaction of cement to proceed. In contrast to many of the above mentioned nanomaterials which have been used in concrete, nano-silica is a pozzolanic material. Thus, nano-silica has dual effects: it increases the performance characteristics of cement paste as a filler in the paste and enhances nucleation effects, it also affects cement paste properties through the pozzolanic reaction [3]. Past research has shown that higher increases in strength can be achieved using nano-silica compared to conventional silica fume [4, 5]. Improvements in hydration kinetics and gel structure have also been observed for nano-silica incorporated cement systems. For example, the apparent reaction rate constant of 4 nm nano-silica has been found as one order of magnitude larger than silica fume [6] and more compacted gel structures with less crystalline hydrates for nano-silica containing cement pastes have also been observed [5, 6].
Nano-silica are amorphous SiO2 nano particles; they can be available in a compacted dry form or in a colloidal dispersion form. Both types of nano-silica have been investigated as a partial replacement material for cement [4, 7-16]. Research outcomes indicate that using the colloidal suspension of nano-silica in concrete has a reduced risk of the nanomaterial forming agglomerates and is better dispersed within the concrete [9, 14]. In the present work, colloidal dispersion of nano-silica was conveniently used in order to maintain an effective dispersion within the paste. Experimental investigations have overwhelmingly shown that nano-silica can increase the strength of concrete when used as a partial weight replacement material of cement for small replacement levels [14, 15, 17-19]. The increase in strength is partly due to the filler effect of the nano particles through inducing more nucleation sites and partly due to the pozzolanic activity of the material. Currently, the majority of the publications report on the effects of nano-silica on strength properties of cement paste, mortar and concrete. A very limited number of publications present the quantification of the hydration characteristics of nano-silica/cement systems [12, 17].
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Nano-silica is a pozzolanic material, thus, it reacts with the CH produced during cement hydration and form secondary type of C-S-H in to the paste. Comparisons between the nano modified samples and the ordinary paste thus gives an indication of the extent of the pozzolanic reactivity of nano-silica within the paste. Experimental techniques commonly used to investigate cementitious materials include X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) [20], Backscatter electron (BSE) image analysis [21], Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) [22, 23], Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) techniques [24], Small angle neutron and X-ray scattering [25], Atomic force microscopy [26] and nanoindentation [17]. Among these methods, TGA and XRPD can provide reliable predictions on the pozzolanic reaction extent based on the CH content of the paste and can be used to analyse the pozzolanic reaction extent more precisely than imaged based techniques [21].
Backscatter electron (BSE) imaging is a widely used method to analyse and observe the microstructure of cementitious materials. Quantifications and analysis using BSE imaging has been used in several areas of interest including identification of micro cracks [27], characterisation of paste [28, 29], reactivity of slag in cementitious materials [30], pore structure analysis [31] and interfacial porosity around aggregate particles [32]. In this paper, BSE imaging along with Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) has been adopted for the quantification of capillary pores and unhydrated cement content of the nano-modified cement paste.
No models predicting the compressive strength characteristics of nano-silica containing cement pastes based on assessing the pozzolanic reactivity of the paste have been presented to date. In the work presented in this paper, a quantification of the CH contents of the cement pastes with and without nano-silica at different ages is carried out based on TGA and XRPD. Through integrating the computed CH contents into currently available cement hydration simulations, a model is developed to predict the volume fractions of different phases present in a nano-silica/cement system. The volume fractions of these phases are also computed separately through analysing backscattered images of the pastes. The results from the BSE imaging are used to validate the model predictions on the volume fractions of the different phases present in nano modified cement paste. Finally, a finite element based model is proposed to predict the compressive strength of the nano modified cement paste. This is based on analysing a Representative Volume Element (RVE) of the paste using the Structural Mechanics Module of COMSOL 4.3a. Experimental data is used to validate the proposed models. Section 2 details the experimental analysis conducted in this research. Section 3

describes the hydration quantification model, followed by the description of the compressive strength prediction model in Section 4. The outcomes of the experimental program and validation of model predictions are discussed in Section 5.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation and characterization of the pastes
sections.text:
The cement used for this study was a General Purpose (GP) cement, conforming to AS 3972- 2010 (Australian Standard for General Purpose and blended cements). The oxide compositions and the physical properties of the cement are detailed in Table 1. Bogue’s composition of the cement is listed Table 2. A colloidal silica sol (Cembinder® 8) supplied by AkzoNobel Pulp and Performance Chemicals AB, Bohus, Sweden was used which contained 50 wt% of solid material [33]. The particle size was 5 nm with a specific surface area of 500 m2/g. Cembinder® 8 consists of sodium stabilized SiO2 particles dispersed in water with specifications stated in Table 3 (as provided by the manufacturer). A polycarboxylate etherbased superplasticizer (specific density 1.06 g/cm3, and 35 wt% solid content) was included in the mix design for better dispersion of nano-silica within the paste and to maintain consistent workability. The flow of the paste was measured through a spread flow cone and the amount of superplasticizer added to a mix was varied until a constant flow reading was achieved among the mixes. Four different blended cement pastes were prepared through replacing the cement content of the mix (by weight) with nano-silica. The mix proportions of the pastes are listed in Table 4. A constant w/b ratio of 0.3 was used for all the samples. The amount of water present in the nano-silica solution was taken into account and the externally added water content was adjusted to maintain a constant w/b ratio.

Mixing of the cement paste samples was performed in a mortar mixer at a speed of 140 ± 5 rpm. In the sample preparation procedure first, the nano-silica suspension was added to half of the water content and stirred well. The superplasticizer was separately added to the rest of the water. In the mixing process, one-third of the nano-silica-water mix was gradually added to the cement along with one-third of the superplasticiser-water mix, followed by one minute mixing. This process was repeated until all the water, nano-silica and superplasticiser was completely added to the paste. After adding all the ingredients, mixing was carried out for an

additional three minutes. The total mixing time per mix is six minutes. The pastes were casted in appropriate moulds for each test as described in the following sections.

sections.heading: 2.2. Thermal calorimetry
sections.text:
Isothermal calorimetry was carried out using TAM Air isothermal calorimeter, at a base temperature of 25 ± 0.02 °C. Externally mixed fresh paste was weighed into an ampoule, and
was instantly placed inside the calorimeter. The heat flow of the first 40 hours of the reaction was recorded. All the obtained values for the heat release rate were normalised by the total weight of cementitious material in the paste.

sections.heading: 2.3. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
After carrying out the mixing as described in Section 2.1, the paste was poured into moulds
and was immediately covered with wet sponges to minimise superficial drying. The specimens were demoulded after 24h and were then moist cured at 23 °C (100% RH). Crushed samples from the hardened cement pastes were taken at 1, 3, 7 and, 28 days age and were ground to form a powder. Acetone was used to stop hydration reactions of the powdered samples and the samples were well dried. The prepared samples were then tested using TGA in a PerkinElmer Diamond instrument. In the TGA procedure, the sample was first held at 30 °C for 20 minutes, and heated from 30 °C to 1000 °C at 10.00 °C/min.

sections.heading: 2.4. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD)
sections.text:
The sample preparation for XRPD study was the same as that for TGA, as described in Section 2.3. The XRPD analysis was carried out using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer. Scans were collected between 5-70° (2θ) with a step size of 0.02° and a scan rate of 5 s per step. An internal standard (10%wt corundum, Al2O3) was added to allow
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
quantitative analysis using Rietveld refinement. Phase identification was completed using Materials Data, Inc., Jade 9.3 software and Quantitative Rietveld analysis using Bruker Diffracplus Topas software.

sections.heading: 2.5. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis
sections.text:
The mixing process described in Section 2.1 was adhered in sample preparation. The cement paste mixes were filled into 25 mm diameter cylindrical tubes and were tapped manually and vibrated slightly. These samples were kept air tight until 28 days was reached. At the day of testing, the samples were removed from the tubes and 10 mm thick disk-shaped slices were obtained from the centre of each cylinder. The freshly cut surface was polished on a lap wheel using silicon carbide abrasive papers of 80, 120, 500, 800,1200 and 2500 grit, respectively. The grinding direction was altered at 90 degrees to ensure that the entire surface has been ground evenly for all the grit sizes. Final polishing was done using 9 µm, 6 µm, and 1µm diamond paste for 180 s each. No action in stopping hydration was taken as the samples were observed for SEM at same day of preparation.
The microstructure of the prepared cement paste sample surfaces were observed under FEI Quanta Scanning Electron Microscope in the low vacuum mode, at a working distance of 10mm and at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The backscattered electron (BSE) imaging along with Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to obtain semi quantitative chemical analyses at different points on the sample. EDS analysis was done equally for all the samples to ensure consistency, and was acquired on several positions of the specimen including the C-S-H, CH and unhydrated particles. Settings for the contrast and brightness of the BSE images were adjusted to make sure that the hydrated phase, unhydrated cement phase and the capillary pores were clearly distinguished in the image. Same settings were maintained for all the samples to ensure consistency.

sections.heading: 2.6. Compressive strength testing
sections.text: The paste mix (prepared as described in Section 2.1) was used to fill cylindrical moulds (h=50 mm, = 25 mm). The moulds were filled in two layers and a vibrated slightly to remove air bubbles. The samples were immediately covered using wet sponges to minimise drying and prevent microcracking. After 24h, the samples were demoulded and moist cured at 23oC (100% RH). Compressive strength of cement paste samples were carried out at 1 day, 3 days, 7 days and 28 days after casting. The flat surfaces of the cylinders were polished in order to eliminate the unevenness. Three samples were tested for each mix using an ELE International compressive strength testing machine with a 2000 kN capacity, and the average value is reported.

sections.heading: 3. Binder hydration quantification method
sections.text: The approach for predicting the influence of nano-silica on the cement paste hydration as proposed in this paper is based on the pozzolanic time dependent reactivity of nano-silica on the paste. Cement hydration produces calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) and calcium hydroxide (CH) compounds. The added nano-silica, which is considered a pozzolanic material, reacts with the CH that is produced by the cement hydration. A comparison of the CH content of the paste containing nano-silica with respect to the plain paste (with cement only) indicates the level of additional hydration reaction that has occurred as a result of change in the binder. In the process, the influence of nano-silica on the cement paste hydration reaction can be established.

sections.heading: 3.3. Different phases present in the paste
sections.text:
Depicting the exact microstructural characteristics of cement paste is not a practical task, but microstructural models can be successfully used to analyse and predict the behaviour of cement pastes. For instance, the smallest capillary pores in the paste are around 8 nm of size, and this level of precision is beyond the capacity of present day computers at acceptable processing time periods. Therefore simplifications of the microstructure need to be done in order to analyse the cement paste. Computation of the overall volumes of phases present in the paste is well enough for the prediction of mechanical properties [35]. The aim of the presented work in this paper is to analyse the compressive strength performance of nanosilica incorporated cement paste. The approach used in this work is to compute the volume percentages of different phases in the cement paste and then building up a representative volume element based on this computation to analyse the compressive strength characteristics.
Existing hydration models are used to predict the volume fractions of different phases present in the hydrated paste at a particular age. The experimental results obtained through TGA and
M AN
US CR
IP T
XRPD are used to integrate the effects of nano-silica on cement hydration characteristics. The nano-modified cement paste is considered to be comprised of four different phases, the hydrated phase, unhydrated cement phase, capillary pore phase, and the unreacted nano-silica phase. Thy hydrated phase is comprised of the constituents resulting from cement hydration, and also the products of hydration occurring due to the pozzolanic reaction of nano-silica. Calcium Silicate Hydrate (C-S-H), Calcium Hydroxide (CH), ettringite and all the other chemical compounds occurring due to hydration, along with the gel pores (0.5 to 10 nm) are lumped together in this phase. In this work, the interconnectivity of the capillary pores are not represented. The pores are symbolized through independent spherical cavities. Powers and Brownyard suggested in [36] that the pore structure of a cement paste having water to cement ratio less than around 0.4 is connected in the scale around 8 nm to 10 nm. This also have been confirmed through mercury intrusion porosimetry [35]. As this connectivity is in the same scale as gel porosity, the interconnected pores have been considered as a part of gel porosity and are included into the hydrated phase.

The nano modified cement paste was considered to be comprised of the above mentioned four phases. The respective volume fractions of the phases are computed in two steps. First, the reaction of ordinary cement is considered, and the volume percentages of the hydrated phase, unhydrated cement phase and the capillary pore phase are computed. Secondly, using the data obtained from TGA and XRPD, the pozzolanic reaction of nano-silica was quantified as described in Section 3.1 and the volume percentages of the phases computed in the previous step are altered, accordingly. sections.heading: 4. Modelling compressive behaviour of the paste
sections.text:
The finite element analysis of the developed Representative Volume Elements (RVE) of the nano-silica including cement pastes were carried out using the Structural Mechanics Module of COMSOL 4.3a. The RVE geometry, which was created in MATLAB, was imported to COMSOL through the LiveLink™ for MATLAB® feature available in COMSOL.
Modelling of the cement paste is carried out through analysing of the cement paste at micro scale using finite elements methods. The RVE represents the given material with regards to geometry and appearance. When determining the size of the RVE, the condition of scale separation was maintained according to [40] so that the RVE size is adequately small to capture the macroscopic behaviour and at the same time it depicts the microstructural heterogeneity of the material. Subsequently, basic homogenisation methods are used to predict the overall macroscopic response [41, 42].
Consistent with experimental work, RVEs of cement pastes with four different percentage replacement levels of cement with nano-silica are considered. The volume fractions of the component phases present within the RVE are computed following the procedure presented in Section 3.4. Based on the calculated volume fractions, the RVE of the paste at micro scale is developed. A cubic shape RVE is generated. The modelling approach for the RVE is presented in Sections 4.1 to 4.3. The different phases present in the paste are represented as randomly distributed spherical particles dispersed within the hydrated phase matrix. The mechanical properties of the individual phases are based on published materials and further
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
discussed in Section 4.2. Up scaling the predicted microstructural properties to the macroscopic scale is carried out considering basic homogenization principles. The main objective of this model is to predict the behaviour of the cement paste subjected to compressive load.

sections.heading: 4.1. Generating RVE geometry
sections.text:
The geometry of the RVE was developed in MATLAB. For a cement paste, the order of the representative volume element is 100-200 µm [35] ,thus the RVE created was a cube of dimensions 100 µm × 100 µm × 100 µm. The hydrated phase is considered to be the matrix material and the other phases were assumed as randomly distributed non-overlapping spherical particles embedded in the hydrated paste matrix. The required number of particles for each embedded phase was computed based on the obtained volume fractions of the respective phases. The capillary pores and unreacted nano-silica were included in the RVE as equal sized spheres. The size of the unhydrated cement particles were considered as a function of the degree of hydration of cement, as according to van Breugel [43]:

sections.heading: 4.2. Material properties of the phases
sections.text:
Hydrated phase: This phase was considered to behave in an elastic-plastic manner. The hydrated phase consists of two major components: the hydrated phase due to cement hydration (Phase A) and the hydrated phase due to the pozzolanic reaction of nano-silica (Phase B). The modulus of elasticity of Phase A was considered to be 23 GPa according to Constantinides and Ulm [44], where a two-step homogenisation model has been developed for the prediction of the elastic modulus of capillary pore free cement paste. Experimental investigations have revealed that the hydration of nano-silica produces more high stiffness CS-H in the mix [14, 45]; therefore, a higher modulus of elasticity value of 30 GPa was assumed for Phase B. The overall modulus of elasticity of the hydrated phase was then
(a) (b) (c)

PT ED
calculated based on the volume fractions of Phases A and B. Poisson’s ratio was assumed as 0.24. The ultimate strength for this phase was considered to be 120 MPa for a cement paste with zero capillary porosity [46].
Unhydrated cement phase: This phase was considered to behave in an elastic-plastic manner with a maximum strength of 40 MPa [47]. The modulus of elasticity and Poisson’s ratio was considered to be 130 GPa and 0.3, respectively [48, 49].
Capillary pore phase: This was represented as voids embedded within the hydrated phase.
Unreacted nano-silica phase: Unreacted nano-silica was considered to behave as a linear elastic material with a modulus of elasticity and Poisson’s ratio as 70 GPa and 0.21, respectively[47].

sections.heading: 4.3. Loading and boundary conditions
sections.text:
The RVE was supported at the bottom surface and prescribed compressive displacements (δz) were applied on the top surface in the negative z direction as shown in Figure 3. Periodic boundary conditions were applied on opposite surfaces as depicted in Figure 4. Considering the geometrical entities present, four-node tetrahedral elements were selected for meshing the RVE for finite element analysis. Capillary pores were not meshed, but were considered as voids embedded within the hydrated phase. The model includes the assumption that the macroscopic stress tensor σ at any random point of the macroscopic continuum is equal to the volume average of the microscopic stress tensor field JK over the domain ΩK of the RVE. Similarly the macroscopic strain tensor ε is obtained through volume averaging the microscopic strain tensor field MK over ΩK [50] as denoted in the following equations.: J = 1/NO JNPQ 24 ΩN M = 1/NO MN PQ 25 ΩN where /K is the volume of the cement paste RVE.

sections.heading: 5.1. Heat of hydration
sections.text:
The heat of hydration curves obtained through isothermal calorimetric analysis are depicted in Figure 5 and Figure 6. It clearly shows that the addition of nano-silica into the paste increases the heat generated over hydration and also increases the reaction rate. Three peaks occur in the hydration process for all the samples in Figure 5. The first peak which is very high (around 0-2 hrs) corresponds to the initial hydration occurring at the surface of cement particles, largely involving C3A. The second peak (around 5-8 hrs) occurs due to the consumption of C3S resulting the formation of C-S-H and CH. The third peak (around 8-13 hrs) is due to the formation of sulphate-type-AFm (monosulphate), either due to the direct hydration of C3A with the sulphate in the solution or due to secondary hydration of C3A with ettringite [51, 52]. The reaction rate increases when the nano-silica content in the paste is increased, which agrees with present available literature [14, 17, 51, 53]. The nucleation effect caused through fine filler materials within cement paste was first recognized in [54, 55]. Nano-silica particles act as a filler material and accelerate the cement hydration process through providing more nucleation sites for the cement particles to hydrate. In a recent work [56], this acceleration has also been attributed to the additional shearing effect caused by the filler material. Therefore the increase in hydration of cement can be explained with the increase in nucleation sites as well as the shearing effect from the filler material (nano-silica). The right hand side of Figure 5 shows the shorter induction period for samples with nanosilica. Nano-silica particles act a filler material in the early stage of hydration resulting accelerated hydration rates when compared to the control sample. This behaviour is improved as the nano-silica content in the mix is increased. However, comparing NS8 and NS12 curves in Figure 5 and Figure 6, it is apparent that NS8 and NS12 do not have a significant difference in the initial heat of hydration characteristics when compared to the control sample. This indicates that replacing the cement content beyond 8% with nano-silica does not have significant impacts on the initial system hydration kinetics.

sections.heading: 5.2. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
TGA analysis was carried out for control mix (plain cement paste), and for 4%, 8% and 12% nano-silica replacement levels for 1day, 3 days, 7 days and 28 days after hydration. The first derivative of the TG data (DTG plots) for each of these mixes at different ages is plotted in Figure 7. Three main peaks are visible in the DTG curves, corresponding to the release of water unbounded and bounded within the C-S-H, ettringite and Afm between 80 oC and 200 oC, dehydroxylation of Ca (OH) 2 around 450 oC and decarbonation of CaCO3 around 680 oC.
Through comparing the DTG curves shown in Figure 7, it can be seen that, for any particular age, with the increase in the nano-silica content in the mix from 0% to 12%, the CH content is decreased. Nano-silica engages in a pozzolanic reaction and consumes the CH, decreasing the free CH content in the mix. Although this behaviour can be seen at any particular time of testing, it is prominently visible after 7 days (i.e. for 7 days and 28 days).

sections.heading: 5.3. Analysis of the XRPD diffraction patterns
sections.text:
The X-ray diffractograms for the cement pastes containing 0%, 4%, 8% and 12% nano-silica contents at 1 day, 3 days, 7 days and 28 days are shown in Figure 8. CH, ettringite, alite, belite and calcite were found to be the major phases present at any time. The presence of the diffraction lines corresponding to CH (Ca(OH)2 , PDF# 004-0733), Ettringite (calcium aluminium sulphate PDF# 041-1451), Alite (tricalcium silicate, C3S, PDF# 00-1347-1356) and Belite (dicalcium silicate, C2S, PDF# 33-0302) are noted. When comparing the intensity of the diffraction lines for a given age, it can be seen that the mixes containing nano-silica have a lower intensity of diffraction lines corresponding to CH when compared to the control mix. This behaviour is more clearly visible after 7 days. As the percentage of nano-silica is increased, the intensities corresponding to CH are decreased. Thus, the pozzolanic reactivity of nano-silica is clearly visible through the X-ray diffractograms. More prominent pozzolanic reactivity can be noted at 7 days and 28 days than the initial stages. This finding agrees with the results discussed in Section 5.2.

sections.heading: 5.4. CH contents
sections.text:
The CH contents of the pastes computed based on Thermal Gravimetric Analysis (TGA) and XRPD are stated in Table 5. It can be seen that the CH content increase over time for all the mixes, due to the hydration of cement proceeding and more CH being produced in the paste. When comparing the CH content at a given age, it is observed that the CH content of the paste is decreased with the increase of nano-silica content in the mix.
The CH content of a nano modified paste at a given age can be reduced due to two reasons. First reason is the dilution phenomenon caused by the introduction of nano-silica into the mix. In other words, the cement content of the paste is reduced due to cement being replaced with nano-silica, and as a result, the amount of CH produced through cement hydration is lower when compared to the plain cement paste. The second reason is the pozzolanic effect of nano-silica. Due to this reason, the normalized values of the CH content can give a more specific idea on the effect of the pozzolanic reaction of nano-silica reinforced cement pastes. If "#$% is less than 1, i.e. if < &'()" . *+, this indicates that nano-silica has resulted in less amount of CH when compared with a mix with same cement content. The lower the value of "#$% the more is the effect of the pozzolanic reaction. At 1 day, not much difference in the normalized CH contents is observed as depicted in Figure 9. At 3 days, "#$% decreases as the nano-silica content is increased. When 7 days is approached, the "#$%values of NS8 and NS12 pastes are almost equal, but at 28 days, the "#$% value of NS8 is less than that of NS12. Though the overall CH content of NS12 at 28 days is lower than that of NS8 (as in Table 5), the normalized value of CH content of NS12 is higher than that of NS8 (as in Figure 9). The cement content replaced through nano-silica is higher for NS12 than that for NS8 and thus, as a lesser cement content is available, the CH produced through cement hydration is less for NS12. The additional nano-silica present in NS12 compared to NS8 does not actively participate in the pozzolanic reaction as adequate CH is not available in the mix. In other words, when comparing the performance of NS8 and NS12, NS8 yields a more effective pozzolanic reactivity.
This argument leads to a conclusion that there should be an optimum replacement level of cement by nano-silica. If the nano-silica content is lower than this optimum level, free CH
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
will be available in the mix, and quantity of nano-silica within the paste will not be adequate to react with this CH present. If the nano-silica content is higher than the optimum level, as the cement content is reduced, adequate CH will not be present to react with the nano-silica and the nano particles will just act as a filler and not participate in the pozzolanic reaction. Through the analysis carried out in this work for the given experimental conditions and type of colloidal nano-silica used in this study, it is apparent that 8% is the optimum cement replacement level with nano-silica in order to obtain a maximum effect through the pozzolanic reactivity.

sections.heading: 5.5. Analysis of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images
sections.text:
Cement paste samples were observed for SEM under the BSE mode at 28 days. Depending on the mean atomic number of a particular phase, the brightness of the phase on the BSE image differs. For a normal cement paste, unhydrated cement phase appears as the brightest. It is then followed by CH and C-S-H, and pores and cracks will be the darkest [21]. The unreacted nano-silica particles are not visible through the BSE image at the observed scale as the particle size is in the nano-metre level. Thus, the image quantification was carried out for the unhydrated phase and the capillary pore phase only.
An image processing software was used to analyse the grey scale of the images. The judgment made by eye on the cut-off grey level for a particular phase can be inaccurate. Therefore, the element maps obtained through EDS were used along with the grey scale of the BSE images to make sure that the cut-off grey level chosen for a particular phase is accurate. A certain grey level was chosen for a particular phase by judgment, and where necessary, element maps were used to identify the phase present on specific points on the BSE image, and the level of the grey scale was altered accordingly.
Figure 10 shows BSE images obtained for the samples at the age of 28 days. The BSE image of the microstructure only shows the two dimensional view of the three dimensional microstructure. Therefore, the area fraction of a particular phase (in 2D) was considered as directly equivalent to the corresponding volume fraction of the phase (in 3D) [21]. As the samples for SEM were cured air tight, a slight over-estimation of the amount of capillary pores can be expected due to self-desiccation occurring within the paste. On the other hand, increase in air trapped can be expected in nano-silica containing pastes at fresh state conditions. This is due to nano-silica particles introducing high gelling tendency and thereby increasing the entrapped air content as observed through experimental results in [57]. As the samples are vibrated after mixing the entrapped air is highly reduced. A study on rheology and fresh state properties of nano-silica incorporated mortars [57] shows that the rate of increasing of the entrapped air content tends to decrease with increasing nano-silica content in the mix. When analysing the images in Figure 10, even though visual observation, it can be
M AN
US CR

seen that, the darker area representing the capillary pores within the paste is highest for the control paste. NS8 sample shows the lowest amount of capillary pores visible. Therefore even though the effect of gelling tendency of nano-silica particles might increasing the entrapped air content is prominent at fresh state, the additional pozzolanic hydration reaction products caused through reaction of nano-silica replaces these air voids at later ages, thereby decreasing the overall capillary porosity as confirmed through the microstructural investigations.
With the increase of nano-silica quantity in the mix, the quantity of the unhydrated cement
phase decreases, and the lowest amount is observed for the NS12. Quantification of the capillary pore phase and the unhydrated cement phase based on the grey scale and the EDS data was carried out for all these samples, and the results are discussed in comparison with the results of the analytical modelling in Section 5.6.

Based on the element composition analyses obtained at various points on the samples, the effects of nano-silica substitution on the chemical composition of the hydrates can be analysed. Figure 11 shows the material composition data plotted based on the Si/Ca and Al/Ca for all four pastes at 28 days. Overall cluster of points seem to shift upwards in Figure 11 as the content of nano-silica is increased in the mix due to the Si included in nano-silica itself. Hydrates form from the pozzolanic reactions of nano-silica with portlandite. These C– S–H, so-called secondary hydrates have a higher Si/Ca ratio of about 0.8, as against 0.58 for conventional Portland cement. The first consequence of this difference is that this C–S–H can absorb, or incorporate into the structure, a larger amount of alkali according to the polarity of the surface of C–S–H. When the Si/Ca is higher, the surface charge of C–S–H becomes negative and more alkali cations can be incorporated into the C–S–H [58, 59].
Through observing Figure 11, it is apparent that the Al/Ca ratio of the paste also increases
with the increase of nano-silica content. The Aluminates are the mobile ions in the system. It is possible that the higher degree of reactivity in nano-silica/cement paste facilitates the substitution of silicon atoms by aluminates in C-S-H chains, to obtain C-A-S-H. This finding agrees with other research done on nano-silica modified cement pastes [14].The modification of the structure of the C-S-H chains positively affects the mechanical properties of the paste. Similar increase in the aluminium substitution in the C-S-H chains has been observed for water and alkali activated pastes blended with metakaolin [60] [61] and slag [62].

sections.heading: 5.6. Analysis of the volume fractions of the phases present in cement paste
sections.text:
The volume fractions of the hydrated phase, unhydrated cement phase, capillary pore phase and the unreacted nano-silica phase were computed as discussed in Section 3.4. Figure 12 shows the volume fractions of these phases against the nano-silica percentage in the paste over time. A slight increase in the quantity of the hydrated phase can be observed in the early ages as the nano-silica content in the paste is increased as depicted in Figure 12(a). At 7 days NS8 has a slightly higher hydrated phase volume fraction than NS12, and at 28 days it can clearly be observed that NS8 has the highest hydrated phase volume fraction. As the hydrated phase is the main strength carrying phase present in cement paste, this makes NS8 to have a higher strength at 28 days than that of NS12. This behaviour was clearly seen in the compressive strength results in Section 5.7.
The volume fraction of the unhydrated cement phase, as reflected in Figure 12(b), decreases over time, due to cement particles being gradually hydrated. The variation of the volume fraction against the nano-silica content follows a linear relationship. The quantity of this phase purely depends on the initial cement content of the paste and the degree of hydration. It

is independent on the reactivity of nano-silica, and thus follows a linear behaviour. The variation of the volume fraction of the capillary pore phase against the nano-silica content is plotted in Figure 12(c). It can be noted that the capillary porosity of the nano modified pastes are always lower than that of the control paste at any time. At the early ages, a significant difference cannot be observed, but at 7 days and significantly for 28 days, NS8 seems to have the least amount of capillary pores. This behaviour was observed in the BSE images obtained depicted in Figure 10 as well. Reduction of the capillary porosity implies increased durability and strength of the paste.
The volume fraction of unreacted nano-silica is plotted in Figure 12(d). The unreacted nanosilica content increases with the increase in the initial nano-silica content in the paste. It can also be noted that the unreacted nano-silica content decreases over time for any particular paste containing nano-silica, as more and more nano-silica gets engage in the pozzolanic reaction over time. The optimum quantity of nano-silica when considering the overall reactivity of the pastes at 28 days is obtained as 8%.
The volume fractions of the unhydrated cement and capillary pores were also obtained through analysing the BSE images as described in Section 5.5. These values have been used to validate the proposed hydration quantification model. Figure 13 shows the comparison of the quantifications obtained through modelling and BSE imaging. As the unreacted nanosilica phase is not clearly visible in the BSE images, the validation was only carried out for the unhydrated cement phase and the capillary pore phase. The results obtained through the hydration model closely agree with the results obtained through analysing BSE images.

sections.heading: 5.7. Compressive strength and model validation
sections.text:
Model predictions of the compressive strength values of the cement pastes are depicted in Figure 14. It can be seen that the model prediction is in good agreement with the experimental data. The optimal replacement level of cement with nano-silica is, once again, found to be around 8% replacement of cement by mass. When the replacement level of cement with nano-silica is greater than 8%, lesser CH contents are observed as discussed in Section 5.4. However, as discussed earlier, the cement content is reduced in mix NS12 compared to the NS8. This makes the overall hydrated phase volume to decrease and the volume of capillary pores to increase. In other words, though the pozzolanic reactivity of NS12 seems to be higher than that of NS8, the decrease in the original cement content of the mix causes a reduction of the overall hydrated phase in the mix. The C-S-H enhancement through the pozzolanic reaction is not adequate to cater the reduction of the overall hydrated phase, thus, the strength of NS12 is less than that of NS8. A cement replacement level around 8% with nano-silica seems to be the optimum mix in order to obtain maximum effects of nano-silica in the paste. However, it is acknowledged that this finding is valid for the cement and nano-silica selected for the current study and for the considered replacement levels of cement. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
This paper demonstrates that the compressive strength performances of cementitious pastes modified with nano-silica can be accurately approximated by using the presented finite element model of a Representative Volume Element. In depth microstructure analysis was carried out to qualify and quantify the changes induced by the integration of nano-silica into a cementitious system. The experimental results strongly agree with the model predicted results. For the type of colloidal silica dispersion used in this study, the model predictions as well as quantifications of the pozzolanic reactivity, initial heat of hydration curves, microstructural analysis and compressive strength examinations clearly indicates that a replacement level around 8 wt% is the optimum replacement level of cement with nanosilica.

metadata.abstractText: A hydration model for Portland cement pastes modified with nano-silica in partial substitution is formulated based on the nucleation growth process from microstructural investigations over time. The model is calibrated against thermogravimetry, X-ray diffraction and calorimetry data for four different substitution rates from 0 to 12 wt% and is validated by backscattered electron microscopy. Finite element based compressive strength predictions using representative volume element analysis of the nano modified cement pastes agreed with the experimental values. The model predictions indicate that a rate of 8 wt% is the optimum replacement level of cement by nano-silica leading to a high density matrix promoting a maximum mechanical strength.
